bestBHT.bht: Paul, being confident of God's faithfulness, affirms that the good work initiated by God, namely their fellowship in the Gospel, will be perfected. This work is a testament to God's goodness and benevolence, and believers should express gratitude and hope. Paul's assurance stems from his belief that God will complete this work, readying it for the day of judgment. Consequently, believers can feel encouraged, eagerly anticipating the blessed resurrection that lies ahead.

Henry Alford: being (i. e. seeing I am) confident of this very thing... that He who began in you a good work... will perfect it."
the one good work in his mind, being their fellowship, &c.
the day has not yet dawned which is to reveal the treasures hidden in hope.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Any work that God begins, He will surely finish.
So as to the particular work here meant, the perfecting of their fellowship in the Gospel.
The Lord's coming, designed by God in every age of the Church to be regarded as near, is to be the goal set before believers' minds rather than their own death.
Albert Barnes: This is strong language. It means to be fully and firmly persuaded or convinced... that is, they would not be convinced.
Paul affirms here that that work was begun by God. It was not by their own agency or will... that he based his firm conviction that it would be permanent.
The Greek word - ἐπιτελέσει epitelesei - means that he would carry it forward to completion; he would perfect it... it means that God would carry on the work which he had begun to completion.
Marvin Vincent: Being confident... since I am confident."
Both were used of religious ceremonials.
John Calvin: For as they are tokens at once of his goodness, and of his fatherly benevolence towards us, what ingratitude were it to derive from this no confirmation of hope and good courage!"

But wherever we see any such tokens of Divine election as can be perceived by us, we ought immediately to be stirred up to entertain good hope, both in order that we may not be envious towards our neighbors, and withhold from them an equitable and kind judgment of charity; and also, that we may be grateful to God."
And in truth, when hope is treated of, our eyes must always be directed forward to a blessed resurrection, as the grand object in view.
Philip Schaff: The good work had been begun in himself, and carried on by the grace of God."
The seed then sown, though exceeding small, God will not suffer to be without fruit.
God will carry on and complete the work in such wise that it shall be ready for the judgment whenever that may come.
Archibald T. Robertson: Being confident (πεποιθως). Second perfect active of πειθω, to persuade.
God began and God will consummate it (see 2 Corinthians 8:6; Galatians 3:3 where both words occur together as here), but not without their cooperation and partnership.
Paul never sets the time for the Lord's return, but he is cheered by that blessed hope.
John Gill: He which hath begun a good work in you, will perform [it] until the day of Jesus Christ.
This is God's work, and not man's.
It is good in its effects; it makes a man a good man, and fits and qualifies him to perform good works, which without it he cannot do.
John Wesley: Being persuaded — The grounds of which persuasion are set down in the following verse.
That he who hath begun a good work in you, will perfect it until the day of Christ — That he who having justified, hath begun to sanctify you, will carry on this work, till it issue in glory.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul confidently asserts that the good work that God has begun in them will surely be perfected. This work, which Paul refers to as their fellowship in the Gospel, is something that God himself initiated and will bring to completion. It is a work that is not only good in its effects, but it also serves as a token of God's goodness and fatherly benevolence towards them. Paul's confidence in the completion of this work is rooted in his firm conviction that God will carry it forward to completion and that it will be ready for the day of judgment, whenever that may come. Thus, believers can be hopeful and encouraged, always looking forward to the blessed resurrection that is the grand object in view.

Paul assures the Philippians that the good work initiated by God, specifically their fellowship in the Gospel, will be brought to perfection. This work is a token of God's goodness and fatherly benevolence, deserving gratitude and inspiring hope. Paul's confidence is based on the conviction that God will carry on and complete this work, ready for the day of judgment. Therefore, believers can be encouraged and look forward to the blessed resurrection as the ultimate goal.

Paul, being confident of God's faithfulness, affirms that the good work initiated by God, namely their fellowship in the Gospel, will be perfected. This work is a testament to God's goodness and benevolence, and believers should express gratitude and hope. Paul's assurance stems from his belief that God will complete this work, readying it for the day of judgment. Consequently, believers can feel encouraged, eagerly anticipating the blessed resurrection that lies ahead.

Paul boldly declares his confidence in God's faithfulness to complete the good work He has begun in them, specifically referring to their fellowship in the Gospel. This work, which is evidence of God's goodness and fatherly benevolence, calls for gratitude and a positive outlook. Paul emphasizes that the completion of this work is not the result of human effort alone, but is a divine work in progress. He assures believers that God will perfect this work, preparing them for the day of Christ's return. This assurance should inspire hope and joyful anticipation.

Paul's confident proclamation is rooted in the assurance that God, who initiated their fellowship in the Gospel, will bring this good work to completion. It is important to recognize that this work is not merely a human endeavor, but a divine work in progress, deserving gratitude and hope. Paul's conviction rests on the belief that God will perfect this work, preparing believers for the day of Christ's return. Hence, there is every reason for believers to be encouraged and eagerly anticipate the fulfillment of this work.
